radioGroup.radio: Yes
No, there are no relative clauses at all

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the clause part occur with respect to the head noun?
radioGroup.radio: Before the head noun
After the head noun
On either side of the head noun, sometimes before and sometimes after

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have relative clauses which are complement clauses (CPs - any of the first three types above)?
radioGroup.radio: Yes

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have relative markers that fill the complementizer position in the complement clause (CP - either the first or third type above)?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, that is the only type of relative clause allowed
Yes, and “wh”-relative clauses are also allowed (like English)
No, only “wh”-relative clauses are allowed

radioGroup.prompt: In the “wh”-relative clauses, can a relative marker also occur in the complementizer position?
radioGroup.radio: No, only the “wh”-word occurs in this type of relative clause, like in English
Yes, the “wh”-word and the relative marker(s) are required to both be present in this type of relative clause
Yes, a relative marker may optionally co-occur along with the “wh”-word in this type of relative clause

radioGroup.prompt: Is the relative marker written as a separate word?
radioGroup.radio: No, it is a clitic which attaches to another word at the edge of the relative clause

radioGroup.prompt: Is the clitic a pro-clitic or a post-clitic?
radioGroup.radio: A proclitic or prefix
An encllitic or suffix
Some of each type
Yes, it is a separate word

radioGroup.prompt: Are any of the relative markers the same as the complementizer used for verbal complement clauses?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, like ‘that’ in English
No, they are all distinct

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the relative marker occur with respect to the sentence part of the relative clause?
radioGroup.radio: Before the sentence
After the sentence
On either side of the sentence, but not both sides at the same time
On either side of the sentence, or both sides at the same time
Before the sentence, or both sides at the same time
After the sentence, or both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the relative markers appear on either side of the sentence?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side
No, they are of the IPregular sentence complement type above, with a relative marker on the verb

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature relative_prefix to these clitics. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature relative_suffix to these clitics. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature relative_prefix to the pro-clitics and add relative_suffix to the post-clitics. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the features makeC relative to each of the relative markers. This will assure the category C so they will occur in the complementizer position and allow their appearance only in a relative clause. Any markers which can occur as the complementizer in a CP which is a complement of a verb, like ‘that’ in English, need to have two separate entries in the lexicon. Mark the second entry with the feature makeC and it will default to not being allowed in relative clauses. (If the same marker can also be used in questions, a third entry is needed with the features makeC question.)

In the lexicon, add the features makeC relative to each of the relative markers. This will assure the category C so they will occur in the complementizer position and allow their appearance only in a relative clause.

In the lexicon, mark those markers which can only occur initially with the feature CP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature CP-final. Do not enter either feature on any markers which can occur on either side.

In the lexicon, add the feature relative to the “wh”-words which can be used in relative clauses. If your language has animacy agreement between the head noun and the wh-relative word (like English “who” versus “which”), also add the feature animate to the animate forms and add the feature -animate to the inanimate forms.
In the lexicon, add the feature relative to each of the affixes that mark relative clauses.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language allow headless relative clauses?
radioGroup.radio: No, a head noun is required
Yes, a head noun may be missing (due to pro-drop, etc.)
